author: HCAndersen
text: FATHER, and mother, and brothers, and sisters, were gone to the play; only little Anna and her grandpapa were left at home.

author: HCAndersen
text: "We'll have a play too," he said, "and it may begin immediately."

author: HCAndersen
text: "But we have no theatre," cried little Anna, "and we have no one to act for us; my old doll cannot, for she is a fright, and my new one cannot, for she must not rumple her new clothes."

author: HCAndersen
text: "One can always get actors if one makes use of what one has," observed grandpapa.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Now we'll go into the theatre.

author: HCAndersen
text: Here we will put up a book, there another, and there a third, in a sloping row.

author: HCAndersen
text: Now three on the other side; so, now we have the side scenes.

author: HCAndersen
text: The old box that lies yonder may be the back stairs; and we'll lay the flooring on top of it.

author: HCAndersen
text: The stage represents a room, as every one may see.

author: HCAndersen
text: Now we want the actors.

author: HCAndersen
text: Let us see what we can find in the plaything-box.

author: HCAndersen
text: First the personages, and then we will get the play ready.

author: HCAndersen
text: One after the other; that will be capital!

author: HCAndersen
text: Here's a pipe-head, and yonder an odd glove; they will do very well for father and daughter."

author: HCAndersen
text: "But those are only two characters," said little Anna.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Here's my brother's old waistcoat- could not that play in our piece, too?"

author: HCAndersen
text: "It's big enough, certainly," replied grandpapa.

author: HCAndersen
text: "It shall be the lover.

author: HCAndersen
text: There's nothing in the pockets, and that's very interesting, for that's half of an unfortunate attachment.

author: HCAndersen
text: And here we have the nut-cracker's boots, with spurs to them.

author: HCAndersen
text: Row, dow, dow! how they can stamp and strut!

author: HCAndersen
text: They shall represent the unwelcome wooer, whom the lady does not like.

author: HCAndersen
text: What kind of a play will you have now?

author: HCAndersen
text: Shall it be a tragedy, or a domestic drama?"

author: HCAndersen
text: "A domestic drama, please," said little Anna, "for the others are so fond of that.

author: HCAndersen
text: Do you know one?"

author: HCAndersen
text: "I know a hundred," said grandpapa.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Those that are most in favor are from the French, but they are not good for little girls.

author: HCAndersen
text: In the meantime, we may take one of the prettiest, for inside they're all very much alike.

author: HCAndersen
text: Now I shake the pen!

author: HCAndersen
text: Cock-a-lorum!

author: HCAndersen
text: So now, here's the play, brin-bran-span new!

author: HCAndersen
text: Now listen to the play-bill."

author: HCAndersen
text: And grandpapa took a newspaper, and read as if he were reading from it:

author: HCAndersen
text: THE PIPE-HEAD AND THE GOOD HEAD A Family Drama in One Act CHARACTERS

author: HCAndersen
text: MR. PIPE-HEAD, a father.

author: HCAndersen
text: MR. WAISTCOAT, a lover.

author: HCAndersen
text: MISS GLOVE, a daughter.

author: HCAndersen
text: MR. DE BOOTS, a suitor.

author: HCAndersen
text: "And now we're going to begin.

author: HCAndersen
text: The curtain rises.

author: HCAndersen
text: We have no curtain, so it has risen already.

author: HCAndersen
text: All the characters are there, and so we have them at hand.

author: HCAndersen
text: Now I speak as Papa Pipe-head!

author: HCAndersen
text: He's angry to-day.

author: HCAndersen
text: One can see that he's a colored meerschaum.

author: HCAndersen
text: "'Snik, snak, snurre, bassellurre!

author: HCAndersen
text: I'm master of this house!

author: HCAndersen
text: I'm the father of my daughter!

author: HCAndersen
text: Will you hear what I have to say?

author: HCAndersen
text: Mr. de Boots is a person in whom one may see one's face; his upper part is of morocco, and he has spurs into the bargain.

author: HCAndersen
text: Snikke, snakke, snak!

author: HCAndersen
text: He shall have my daughter!"

author: HCAndersen
text: "Now listen to what the Waistcoat says, little Anna," said grandpapa.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Now the Waistcoat's speaking.

author: HCAndersen
text: The Waistcoat has a laydown collar, and is very modest; but he knows his own value, and has quite a right to say what he says: "'I haven't a spot on me!

author: HCAndersen
text: Goodness of material ought to be appreciated.

author: HCAndersen
text: I am of real silk, and have strings to me.'

author: HCAndersen
text: "'- On the wedding day, but no longer; you don't keep your color in the wash.'

author: HCAndersen
text: This is Mr. Pipe-head who is speaking.

author: HCAndersen
text: 'Mr. de Boots is water-tight, of strong leather, and yet very delicate; he can creak, and clank with his spurs, and has an Italian physiognomy-'" "But they ought to speak in verses," said Anna, "for I've heard that's the most charming way of all."

author: HCAndersen
text: "They can do that too," replied grandpapa; "and if the public demands it, they will talk in that way.

author: HCAndersen
text: Just look at little Miss Glove, how she's pointing her fingers!

author: HCAndersen
text: "'Could I but have my love, Who then so happy as Glove!

author: HCAndersen
text: Ah!

author: HCAndersen
text: If I from him must part, I'm sure 'twill break my heart!' 'Bah!'

author: HCAndersen
text: The last word was spoken by Mr. Pipe-head; and now it's Mr. Waistcoat's turn:

author: HCAndersen
text: "'O Glove, my own dear, Though it cost thee a tear, Thou must be mine, For Holger Danske has sworn it!'

author: HCAndersen
text: "Mr. de Boots, hearing this, kicks up, jingles his spurs, and knocks down three of the side-scenes."

author: HCAndersen
text: "That's exceedingly charming!" cried little Anna.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Silence! silence!" said grandpapa.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Silent approbation will show that you are the educated public in the stalls.

author: HCAndersen
text: Now Miss Glove sings her great song with startling effects:

author: HCAndersen
text: "'I can't see, heigho!

author: HCAndersen
text: And therefore I'll crow!

author: HCAndersen
text: Kikkeriki, in the lofty hall!'

author: HCAndersen
text: "Now comes the exciting part, little Anna.

author: HCAndersen
text: This is the most important in all the play.

author: HCAndersen
text: Mr. Waistcoat undoes himself, and addresses his speech to you, that you may applaud; but leave it alone,- that's considered more genteel.

author: HCAndersen
text: "'I am driven to extremities!

author: HCAndersen
text: Take care of yourself!

author: HCAndersen
text: Now comes the plot!

author: HCAndersen
text: You are the Pipe-head, and I am the good head- snap! there you go!"

author: HCAndersen
text: "Do you notice this, little Anna?" asked grandpapa.

author: HCAndersen
text: "That's a most charming comedy.

author: HCAndersen
text: Mr. Waistcoat seized the old Pipe-head and put him in his pocket; there he lies, and the Waistcoat says: "'You are in my pocket; you can't come out till you promise to unite me to your daughter Glove on the left.

author: HCAndersen
text: I hold out my right hand.'"

author: HCAndersen
text: "That's awfully pretty," said little Anna.

author: HCAndersen
text: "And now the old Pipe-head replies:

author: HCAndersen
text: "'Though I'm all ear, Very stupid I appear: Where's my humor?

author: HCAndersen
text: Gone, I fear, And I feel my hollow stick's not here, Ah! never, my dear, Did I feel so queer.

author: HCAndersen
text: Oh! pray let me out, And like a lamb led to slaughter I'll betroth you, no doubt, To my daughter.'"

author: HCAndersen
text: "Is the play over already?" asked little Anna.

author: HCAndersen
text: "By no means," replied grandpapa.

author: HCAndersen
text: "It's only all over with Mr. de Boots.

author: HCAndersen
text: Now the lovers kneel down, and one of them sings:

author: HCAndersen
text: "'Father!'

author: HCAndersen
text: and the other,

author: HCAndersen
text: 'Come, do as you ought to do,- Bless your son and daughter.'

author: HCAndersen
text: And they receive his blessing, and celebrate their wedding, and all the pieces of furniture sing in chorus,

author: HCAndersen
text: "'Klink! clanks!

author: HCAndersen
text: A thousand thanks; And now the play is over!'

author: HCAndersen
text: "And now we'll applaud," said grandpapa.

author: HCAndersen
text: "We'll call them all out, and the pieces of furniture too, for they are of mahogany."

author: HCAndersen
text: "And is not our play just as good as those which the others have in the real theatre?"

author: HCAndersen
text: "Our play is much better," said grandpapa.

author: HCAndersen
text: "It is shorter, the performers are natural, and it has passed away the interval before tea-time."
